steps: The thought of gaining weight scares me
I refrain from eating even when I feel hungry
I often catch myself thinking about food
I have had episodes of overeating when I felt completely out of control
I cut the food on my plate into very small pieces
I know how many calories are in the food I eat
I avoid foods that are high in carbohydrates (such as bread, potatoes, rice, etc.)
I feel that other people would prefer me to eat more
I feel nauseous after eating
I feel strong guilt after eating
I constantly think about how to lose weight
I think about burning calories when I exercise
People around me say I am too thin
I am preoccupied with the amount of fat on my body
It takes me longer to finish a meal than it takes other people
I avoid foods that contain sugar
I eat diet foods
I feel that food-related issues are controlling my life
I have self-control when it comes to food
I feel that people around me are pressuring me to eat
I spend too much time and mental energy thinking about food
I feel discomfort and anxiety after eating sweets
I am on a diet
I like the feeling of having an empty stomach
After eating, I sometimes have a strong impulse to make myself vomit
I enjoy trying new and tasty dishes

0.text: Fear of gaining weight is often associated with eating disorders such as anorexia nervosa. This fear can become so intense that it leads to avoiding certain foods and engaging in excessive physical activity.
0.fact: Research shows that fear of weight gain is one of the main predictors of anorexia and bulimia, especially among teenagers and young adults. Seeking help and receiving support from others are crucial for successful recovery.

1.text: Deliberately not eating even when you feel hungry can be a sign of an eating disorder such as anorexia nervosa. It is often linked to a strong desire to control weight and body shape, which can lead to serious health problems.
1.fact: Restricting food intake can create a sense of control that temporarily reduces anxiety about weight and body image. However, over time it can increase anxiety and depression due to physical strain and psychological distress.

2.text: Intrusive thoughts about food can heighten anxiety and stress, creating a vicious cycle in which thoughts about food trigger anxiety, and anxiety leads to even more thoughts about food. This can seriously lower quality of life and interfere with everyday tasks.
2.fact: Studies suggest that about 1% of women and 0.5% of men experience anorexia, and up to 4% of women and 2% of men may experience bulimia at some point in their lives. Intrusive thoughts about food are one of the core symptoms of these conditions.

3.text: Episodes of uncontrolled overeating are a key symptom of binge eating disorder and bulimia. During such episodes, a person may consume large amounts of food in a short period of time while feeling unable to stop.
3.fact: Binge eating is often followed by guilt, shame and low mood. These painful emotions can make the disorder worse and maintain the cycle of overeating and emotional suffering.

4.text: Cutting food into small pieces can be associated with eating disorders such as anorexia nervosa. This behaviour can slow down eating and create the illusion of a larger portion, helping a person feel less hungry.
4.fact: These rituals are often attempts to maintain control over eating. People with eating disorders may rely on such behaviours to reduce anxiety related to food and weight.

5.text: Constantly counting calories can be linked to eating disorders such as anorexia and bulimia. It can become an obsessive habit that shapes food choices and mealtimes, promoting calorie restriction and excessive control over diet.
5.fact: Calorie counting can come to dominate a person’s thinking and disrupt normal eating and social life. It can contribute to social withdrawal, avoidance of food-related events and worsening mental health.

6.text: Avoiding foods rich in carbohydrates can be related to eating disorders such as anorexia and orthorexia. People may stay away from these foods because they fear gaining weight or want to keep strict control over their diet.
6.fact: Restricting carbohydrates can trigger strong guilt or shame if these foods are eaten. This can lead to even tighter control and further avoidance of food, which increases anxiety and negative body image.

7.text: People with eating disorders often feel pressure from loved ones who worry about their health and diet. This can create extra stress and guilt in someone who already finds eating difficult.
7.fact: Public figures such as Demi Lovato have spoken openly about their struggles with eating disorders and how pressure from others affected their self-image and eating habits. She emphasizes the importance of understanding and support from those around her.

8.text: Stress and anxiety around eating can trigger psychosomatic reactions such as nausea and vomiting. These symptoms often intensify when a person feels guilty or ashamed after eating.
8.fact: Frequent nausea and vomiting can lead to serious medical complications, including dehydration, nutrient deficiencies, electrolyte imbalances and damage to the oesophagus. These conditions require medical attention.

9.text: Feeling guilty after eating is a common symptom of eating disorders such as bulimia and anorexia. This guilt is often linked to breaking strict dietary rules or eating “forbidden” foods.
9.fact: Ongoing guilt after meals can fuel a cycle of restriction and overeating, making the disorder worse. Studies suggest that around 30% of people with eating disorders experience strong guilt and shame after meals, which underlines the need for early intervention and treatment.

10.text: Excessive focus on weight loss can trigger or intensify anxiety, depression and low self-esteem. It is often accompanied by a negative body image and a strong desire to meet unrealistic beauty standards.
10.fact: According to the U.S. National Institutes of Health, about 1% of women and 0.5% of men experience anorexia, and one of the main features of this condition is constant preoccupation with the need to lose weight.

11.text: Obsessive thoughts about calories and weight can heighten anxiety and stress related to physical activity. People may feel guilty or ashamed if they do not reach their exercise targets or do not burn “enough” calories.
11.fact: This approach to exercise can lead to excessive and exhausting workouts, increasing the risk of injury and burnout. It can also result in giving up exercise when a person feels unable to meet their unrealistic goals.

12.text: Being noticeably underweight can be a sign of eating disorders such as anorexia nervosa. People with this condition often have a distorted body image and strive to lose even more weight, even when those around them are already worried.
12.fact: Comments from others can increase anxiety and stress in someone with an eating disorder. This may push them to control their weight even more tightly and avoid food, which worsens the condition.

13.text: Constant thoughts about body fat can increase anxiety, stress and dissatisfaction with one’s body. This is often linked to low self-esteem and perfectionism, which worsen mental health and can lead to depression.
13.fact: People preoccupied with body fat may resort to extreme measures to reduce it, including fasting, excessive exercise and misuse of laxatives or diuretics. These behaviours can cause serious harm to physical health.

14.text: Eating very slowly can be a way of managing anxiety around food. It may include cutting food into tiny pieces, chewing for a long time and taking long pauses between bites. This behaviour can be a sign of obsessive control over eating.

15.text: Avoiding sugar can increase rigid control over food and contribute to the development of unhealthy eating habits. It can also lead to low energy and a lack of key nutrients the body needs to function properly.
15.fact: Research shows that balanced sugar intake as part of a healthy diet is important for maintaining energy levels and stable mood. Completely cutting out sugar without medical reasons can lead to nutrient deficiencies and a lower overall quality of life.

16.text: In many Western cultures, diet products are strongly associated with a “healthy lifestyle”. However, this can put pressure on people, pushing them to follow strict dietary rules and avoid social situations that involve food.

17.text: Being overly preoccupied with food can affect work, studies and personal relationships. People may spend considerable time planning, buying and preparing food, as well as exercising, leaving less time for other important areas of life.

18.text: Self-control around food can be both helpful and harmful. In the context of eating disorders such as anorexia or orthorexia, excessive self-control can lead to strict food restrictions and unhealthy eating patterns.

19.text: People with eating disorders often experience pressure from others to eat more or to eat in a particular way. This pressure can come from family, friends or colleagues and can increase stress and anxiety.

20.text: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) is an effective treatment for eating disorders that focuses on changing unhelpful thoughts and behaviours related to food. This approach helps people develop a healthier relationship with eating and reduce intrusive thoughts about food.

21.text: Sweets can cause a rapid rise in blood sugar followed by a sharp drop. This can contribute to feelings of fatigue, irritability and low mood, which in turn can intensify anxiety.

22.text: Being on a diet can be part of a healthy lifestyle, but it can also be a sign of eating disorders such as anorexia, orthorexia or bulimia. Very strict diets are often associated with excessive control around food and anxiety about weight and appearance.
22.fact: Studies suggest that about 50% of people who follow restrictive diets develop disordered eating patterns. This highlights the importance of being aware of the risks of dieting and seeking help when problems arise.

23.text: For some people, the feeling of an empty stomach is associated with success and self-control. This state can temporarily reduce anxiety and create a sense of achievement, especially when the goal is weight loss.
23.fact: Constantly striving for the feeling of an empty stomach can lead to nutrient deficiencies, dehydration, weakness and a weakened immune system. Prolonged fasting can cause serious medical complications, including organ damage.

24.text: Frequent self-induced vomiting can lead to serious medical complications such as electrolyte imbalances, dehydration, damage to the oesophagus and teeth, and cardiovascular problems. These conditions can be life-threatening and require immediate medical intervention.

25.text: Taking pleasure in trying new and tasty foods is a sign of a healthy relationship with eating. It helps diversify the diet, provides the body with essential nutrients and supports overall wellbeing.
25.fact: Enjoying food can improve mood and reduce stress. When we take pleasure in what we eat, the body releases endorphins that promote feelings of happiness and satisfaction.

range.low: Low likelihood of an eating disorder
range.middle: Moderate likelihood of an eating disorder
range.high: High likelihood of an eating disorder

low.text: Your result suggests a low likelihood of an eating disorder. This indicates that your eating behaviour is generally within a typical range. At the same time, it is important to remember that this test does not replace a professional diagnosis. If you have any questions or concerns related to eating or body image, speaking with a specialist can offer additional clarity and support.
low.title: Low likelihood of an eating disorder

middle.text: Your result shows that you may have certain patterns or difficulties related to eating behaviour. This does not necessarily mean you have an eating disorder, but it may be helpful to discuss the result with a specialist to receive a more accurate assessment and recommendations. Try not to worry ahead of time — treat this as an opportunity to get support and improve your wellbeing.
middle.title: Moderate likelihood of an eating disorder

high.text: Your result points to a high likelihood of significant difficulties related to eating behaviour. This may have a noticeable impact on your emotional state, health and quality of life. Please consider reaching out to a specialist for professional support. You are not alone — there are many resources and qualified professionals who can help you rebuild a healthier relationship with food and your body.
high.title: High likelihood of an eating disorder

text: This test is based on the Eating Attitudes Test (EAT-26), developed at the Clarke Institute of Psychiatry in Toronto and widely used by professionals around the world to assess eating behaviour. It helps to identify possible difficulties related to anorexia, bulimia, restrictive eating and compulsive overeating.
